text.p: American Stacy Dragila proved the field in the women's pole vault is stronger than many thought with her surprise victory at the world indoor championships on Sunday.
Dragila, a former hurdler, shocked ex-trapeze artist Emma George of Australia who holds both the indoor and outdoor world marks and was expected to walk away with the title.
Instead it was the 25-year-old American who equalled the Australian's indoor mark and claimed the first gold medal ever handed out in the women's pole vault at a major championships.
"There were a few us out there jumping really great height," said Dragila, who will compete in a full decathlon next month.
"I think in the next couple of years you're going to see it improve even more and take off.
"Emma is a great athlete but I know there's other girls eager for these world championships' titles and capable of jumping great heights.
"It was very difficult for me to take on the pole vault because I don't have the gymnastics background and when I first started doing it I was really scared to go upside down."
George, who has quickly become to women's pole vaulting what Sergei Bubka is to the men's event, has established eight world records in the last two years.
The acrobatic Australian has brought the event credibility and attention.
"I just love pole vaulting," said George, who had to settle for the silver with a vault of 4.35. "I like to improve on what I've done before.
"The higher the record gets the more acceptable the event will be."
The strawberry-blonde athlete is not only her sport's brightest star but its most marketable commodity.
On Sunday it was Dragila, earning $25,000 for her efforts, who stole the limelight.
"I think women will be going 4.80 by 2000. I don't think that is unrealistic at all," Dragila said.
"I couldn't imagine having $25,000 in my hand when I have been surviving on $15,000 between me and my husband."
